title: 3 Quick & Easy Ways to Clone a GitHub Repository (With Pictures)

steps.title: Download and install Git.
steps.content: Download and install Git. Go to https://git-scm.com/downloads and select the download for the platform you are using.

steps.title: Create a directory for your repository.
steps.content: Create a directory for your repository. Navigate to a location of your choosing in your computer. Then right-click (or Ctrl + click) and select "New Folder". For simplicity, it may be best to create your first repository folder on the Desktop.

steps.title: Open Git CMD.
steps.content: Open Git CMD. This program is installed along with the git tools, however you can also use the natively installed Command Prompt (Windows) or Terminal (Mac/Linux).

steps.title: Navigate to your target directory in the command line.
steps.content: Navigate to your target directory in the command line. Enter the "cd" command followed by the path to the repository folder you created. Folders in the path are separated by "\". Hit ↵ Enter to complete the action. For example, a folder on the desktop for Windows would use the command "cd c:\users\[username]\desktop\[foldername]" "cd" stands for "change directory" You can change directories one at a time instead of all at once if you find it faster to type: "cd desktop" ↵ Enter "cd folder name" ↵ Enter .

steps.title: Navigate to the repository page in your web browser.
steps.content: Navigate to the repository page in your web browser. Go to the GitHub (or whichever git alternative) page of the repository you are trying to clone. The source location of the repository will be displayed on the repository page. The exact location of the source location will vary depending on which repository site you are using, but they are usually located near the top for easy access. On GitHub, the source locations will be under a green button that says Code .

steps.title: Copy the source location.
steps.content: Copy the source location. Click the source location (typically a URL starting with "https" or "ssh") and hit Ctrl + C or ⌘ Cmd + C to copy.

steps.title: Enter "git clone" followed by the source location into the command line.
steps.content: Enter "git clone" followed by the source location into the command line. The "git" command tells the command line you are using a Git function, and "clone" tells it to clone the location following the command. Paste or type out the source location after the command. In order to paste into the Windows command line, you have to right-click and select "Paste" from the context menu. This is not necessary in the Mac or Linux Terminal.

steps.title: Hit ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Hit ↵ Enter . The cloning process will begin and display its progress in the command line. You will be notified when the process in completed by a message in the command line.

steps.title: Open Git GUI.
steps.content: Open Git GUI. This program is installed along with the git tools. Instead of booting into a text command line, you will see a window with clickable buttons.

steps.title: Click "Clone Repository".
steps.content: Click "Clone Repository". This is the first option on the boot splash screen. You can also select "Clone" from "Repository" dropdown menu.

steps.title: Enter the source location.
steps.content: Enter the source location. Paste or type the source location into this field.

steps.title: Enter target directory.
steps.content: Enter target directory. Enter the path to the repository folder you created. You can also click "Browse" to search for the folder without having to type it out.

steps.title: Click "Clone".
steps.content: Click "Clone". The GUI will display your progress and notify you once the clone is complete.

steps.title: Open Visual Studio.
steps.content: Open Visual Studio. Visual Studio is common in Windows development environments, but is not free. You can download VS Express to get a stripped down free edition.

steps.title: Select the "Team Explorer" tab.
steps.content: Select the "Team Explorer" tab. This is located in the bottom of right-hand sidebar.

steps.title: Click the "Manage Connections" button.
steps.content: Click the "Manage Connections" button. This button is represented by the plug icon and is located in the top menu bar of the right sidebar.

steps.title: Click "Clone".
steps.content: Click "Clone". This is located in the "Local git repositories" section in the right sidebar.

steps.title: Enter or paste the source location into the text field.
steps.content: Enter or paste the source location into the text field. Once in the field, the "Clone" action button will become clickable.

steps.title: Click "Clone".
steps.content: Click "Clone". This button is located below the source location field. Once clicked a progress bar will appear displaying the clone process. The process is complete once the bar is filled. Cloned repositories are automatically cloned to a local directory in your visual studio directory. [2] X Research source
